title: Current State of Advanced Practice Providers in Urological Practice
abstract: No AccessUrology PracticeWhite Paper1 Jan 2022Current State of Advanced Practice Providers in Urological PracticeThis article is commented on by the following:Editorial Commentary Timothy C. Brand, Ken Mitchell, Susanne Quallich, Jonathan Rubenstein, Kathleen Zwarick Shanley, Andrea Gutierrez, Gwen Hooper, Jay Motola, Brooke Zilinskas, Jennifer Robles, Brad Erickson, Eugene Rhee, and Aaron Spitz Timothy C. BrandTimothy C. Brand *Correspondence: Baptist Health Care,Pensacola, Florida E-mail Address: [email protected] Baptist Health Care,Pensacola, Florida More articles by this author , Ken MitchellKen Mitchell Arkansas Urology, Little Rock, Arkansas More articles by this author , Susanne QuallichSusanne Quallich University of Michigan School of Nursing, Ann Arbor, Michigan More articles by this author , Jonathan RubensteinJonathan Rubenstein Chesapeake Urology Associates, Baltimore, Maryland More articles by this author , Kathleen Zwarick ShanleyKathleen Zwarick Shanley American Urological Association, Linthicum, Maryland More articles by this author , Andrea GutierrezAndrea Gutierrez American Urological Association, Linthicum, Maryland More articles by this author , Gwen HooperGwen Hooper University of Alabama Capstone College of Nursing, Tuscaloosa, Alabama More articles by this author , Jay MotolaJay Motola Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, New York More articles by this author , Brooke ZilinskasBrooke Zilinskas University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, Texas More articles by this author , Jennifer RoblesJennifer Robles Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee More articles by this author , Brad EricksonBrad Erickson University of Iowa Hospitals & Clinics, Iowa City, Iowa More articles by this author , Eugene RheeEugene Rhee Kaiser Permanente San Diego, San Diego, California More articles by this author , and Aaron SpitzAaron Spitz Orange County Urology Associates, Laguna Hills, California More articles by this author View All Author Informationhttps://doi.org/10.1097/UPJ.0000000000000278AboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissionsReprints ShareFacebookLinked InTwitterEmail Abstract Introduction: This document provides an update to the 2015 consensus statement with new content on inpatient utilization, procedural data, and compensation. The full document is available on the American Urological Association (AUA) website (https://www.auanet.org/guidelines/guidelines/current-state-of-advanced-practice-providers-in-urologic-practice). This document was created by an ad-hoc group of urological providers formed by the AUA board of directors. Methods: A workforce shortage of 65,000 physicians is projected by the year 2025. In 2018, there were 3.89 urologists per capita, which is amongst the most severe specialty shortages. Urology has the second oldest surgical subspecialty workforce with an average age of 52.5 years. According to the 2018 census, 72.5% of urologists used an advanced practice provider (APP) in their practice, and APPs accounted for 41% of a medical doctor/doctor of osteopathy full-time equivalent. The AUA endorses the use of APPs in the care of patients through a formally defined, supervised role with a board certified urologist under the auspices of applicable state law. This physician-led, team-based approach provides the highest quality urological care. Results: Urologists work with APPs frequently, but many may not know the most efficient way to incorporate them into their practice. This document examines APP integration from a regulatory and practice management approach, as well as provides information on inpatient utilization, procedural data, and compensation. Conclusions: This document supports the AUA’s policy statement that in a team-based approach with a board certified urologist in a supervisory role, APPs contribute to the care of the patient with genitourinary disease and, therefore, encourages the proper use of APPs.
